A Ni(III) complex with a Ni(II) counterpart, formulated as 2[Ni(L)(HL)(SCN)].0.5[Ni(Cl)(SCN)3].0.5(SCN) (1), and a Ni(II) complex, [Ni(L)(NCS)] (2), were synthesized using the Schiff base ligand (E)-4‑bromo-2-(((2-(dimethylamino)ethyl)imino)methyl)-6-methoxyphenol [HL]. Both complexes were structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The high oxidation state of the metal in 1 was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), cyclic voltammetry (CV), and EPR analysis study, which, as far as our survey shows, represents the first report of a Ni(III) complex comprising Schiff base ligands with a Ni(II) counterpart. The presence of the Lewis acidic nickel center, as well as the Lewis basic groups (-NMe2 or -OMe) in both complexes, makes them suitable as catalysts for carbon dioxide fixation into epoxides for the production of organic cyclic carbonates. The use of greenhouse gas CO2 (at 1 bar) and solvent-free conditions marks the catalytic protocol as environment friendly. Various aliphatic, aromatic, and endocyclic epoxides smoothly undergo the fixation reaction through this catalytic process, producing the respective carbonate products in moderate to high yields (51–100 %) at 90 °C. The conditions of these catalytic reactions were optimized, and high turnover numbers (TON) of 1224–2400, along with turnover frequencies of 66–200 h–1, were achieved. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used to determine the relative energy of transition states, intermediates, and products involved in the catalytic cycles and to describe the mechanistic pathway in detail. Graphical abstract Nickel (III) complex with Ni(II) counterpart, 2[Ni(L)(HL)(SCN)].0.5[Ni(Cl)(SCN)3].0.5(SCN), and a Ni(II) complex [NiII(L)(NCS)], synthesized and structurally characterized, behave as good catalysts for the CO2 fixation to epoxides to form cyclic carbonates with high TON/TOF. The +3 oxidation state of compound 1 is confirmed by BVS calculation, X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy, UV–Vis spectra and EPR spectroscopy analysis. A plausible catalytic reaction mechanism is also framed from DFT calculations. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni(III) complex X-ray crystal structure XPS study EPR study CO2 fixation Organic cyclic carbonate Theoretical calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The concentration of prime green-house gas carbon dioxide has increased enormously due to rapid urbanization and industrial emissions [1–4]. As a consequence of global warming, abnormal climate changes are occurring. Thus utilization of CO2 in chemical fixation reactions achieves great attentions from global scientific communities [5–10], and only few countries have been trying to recycle carbon dioxide from industrial emissions and atmosphere. Due to cheap, abundant, renewable C1-building block as well as multi-electron reductions for C−C bond formation, the use of carbon dioxide in organic production is of perpetual interest [11–14]. The multi-electron reduction involving two electron−two proton reduction of carbon dioxide affords the formation of carbon monoxide, which can be transformed into methane and methanol via two electron−two proton and four electron−four proton reductions, respectively. Again, single electron reduction of carbon dioxide gives rise to CO2*−, which is capable to produce CO and CO3 2−through a disproportionation reaction and finally generates formate in aqueous medium.14c Moreover, CO2 undergoes coupling or cross coupling reaction with organic substrates such as coupling with carbanion or organo-zinc to produce carboxylic acids [15], and cross-coupling with epoxides to form cyclic carbonates or polycarbonates [16]. In nature, transition metal-containing enzymes catalytically facilitate carbon dioxide fixation reactions; for example, the [NiFe4S4] active site in carbon monoxide dehydrogenase (CODH) is capable of either reducing CO2 to CO or oxidizing CO to CO2 [17–19]. Additionally, carbonic anhydrase (CA), a zinc-containing enzyme, catalyzes the reaction to form CO3 2− from CO2 through a non-redox pathway, and the embedded magnesium in the d-ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate oxygenase/carboxylase protein fixes carbon dioxide in plants [20–27]. All these enzymatic processes offer advantages such as high yield, atom economy, specificity, low energy cost, and strong tolerance to catalyst poisoning [28–32]. From the above concerns, the use of transition metal-based catalysts for carbon dioxide fixation appears quite logical. Although CO2 is a valuable C1 feedstock for chemical fixation reactions, it is thermodynamically stable, and the reaction requires high activation energy. Thus, a catalyst is essential for the activation and chemical fixation of CO2. On the other hand, around 24,000 million tons of carbon dioxide are released into the atmosphere per year from industrial emissions, but only 120 million tons (<1 % of emitted CO2) are used in the chemical industry for the production of valuable chemicals, including urea [5]. This issue clearly reveals that the transformation of CO2 is only partly compensated by the chemical industry due to the lack of availability of appropriate catalysts. One of the finest CO2 fixation reactions is the coupling reaction between epoxides and CO2 to produce cyclic carbonates [33]. The process is 100 % atom economical, and the resulting cyclic carbonates are widely applied as solvents for electrolytes in Li-ion batteries, raw materials for cosmetics, sustainable polar aprotic solvents, and intermediates for the synthesis of polymers or fine chemicals [34–37]. A number of transition metal catalysts containing metals such as iron [38], copper [39], cobalt [40], zinc [41], chromium [42], manganese [43], and vanadium [44] have been reported to date for the production of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides. However, a limited number of Ni(II)-based catalysts have been described for this process [45,46], and a Ni(III) complex is unlikely to behave as a catalyst. All these reports, however, suffer from the utilization of carbon dioxide at high pressure, and only recently a few publications have reported nickel(II)-based catalysts that use CO2 fixation at 1 atmosphere [47]. A few organometallic Ni(III) complexes were previously reported by Mirica et al. [48] therefore, the present work is the first report of a Ni(III) complex in a Schiff base ligand environment. Taking into account the described considerations, in this article, a Schiff base ligand, (E)−4‑bromo-2-(((2-(dimethylamino)ethyl)imino)methyl)−6-methoxyphenol [HL], was used to synthesize a nickel(III) compound 2[Ni(L)(HL)(SCN)].0.5[Ni(Cl)(SCN)3].0.5(SCN)(1) and a nickel(II) complex [NiII(L)(NCS)] (2), both of which were structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The high oxidation state (+3) of complex 1 was authenticated not only by single crystal X-ray diffraction but also by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), EPR, and electrochemical analysis. Both complexes were highly suitable as catalysts for the fixation of carbon dioxide (under 1 bar pressure) with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates. Both terminal and internal epoxides smoothly underwent this catalytic reaction, producing the desired products in moderate to high yields at 90 °C in 10–18.5 h of reaction. Moreover, theoretical calculations were carried out to establish the probable mechanistic pathway for the carbon dioxide fixation reaction. Experimental Preparation of the ligand (HL) The ligand HL was synthesized by following the previously reported method (Scheme 1 ) [49]. Synthesis of complex 1 NiCl2·6H2O (2.5 mmol, 0.5875 g) was reacted with the ligand (E)−4‑bromo-2-(((2-(dimethylamino)ethyl)imino)methyl)−6-methoxyphenol (HL) (2 mmol, 0.600 g) in methanolic medium under stirring. With the addition of NaSCN (2 mmol, 0.160 g) and triethylamine (2 mmol, 0.202 g), a clear yellow solution was obtained. The resulting solution turned brown after continuous stirring for 2 h. The solution was then left undisturbed, and dark brown crystals of complex 1 (Scheme 1), suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, appeared after a few days. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with cold water, and dried in air. (Yield: 63.4 %). Anal. Calc. for C104H132Br8ClN24Ni5O16S8 (M.W 3199.09): C, 39.05; H, 4.16; N, 10.51. Found: C, 39.08; H, 4.12; N, 10.57 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1023 (m), 1244 (s), 1647 (s), 2105 (m). Synthesis of complex 2 The reaction of compound 1 (0.04 mmol, 0.128 g) with KPF6 (1 mmol, 0.184 g) in methanol/acetonitrile medium was stirred at room temperature and the resulted clear red solution gave red single crystals after evaporation within 5 days. (Yield: 48 %). Anal. Calc. for C13H16BrN3NiO2S (M.W 416.97): C, 37.45; H, 3.87; N, 10.08. Found: C, 37.48; H, 3.83; N, 10.10 %. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1080 (m), 1232(s), 1448 (s), 1547 (s), 2068 (m). Results and discussion Structural description of complexes 1 and 2 Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P 1 ¯ , and the X-ray structural analysis evidenced the presence of two mononuclear complex cations in the asymmetric unit (Fig. 1 (a) and (b)) counterbalanced by disordered SCN⁻ and [Ni(Cl)(SCN)3][2]– anions (see experimental section). The configuration of the two cations is closely comparable, with the Ni atom in a distorted octahedral geometry formed by two Schiff base ligands, where the imino nitrogen atoms of the two ligands are trans-located and a terminal SCN⁻ anion is bound via the nitrogen donor. One ligand, incorporating N2O2 donor atoms, binds the metal at three meridional sites with the phenoxo, imino, and amino nitrogen donors, while the other acts as a chelating ligand, with the nitrogen of dimethylamino moiety being protonated. Thus, complex 1, as derived from the diffraction analysis, can be formulated as 2[Ni(L)(HL)(SCN)].0.5[Ni(Cl)(SCN)3].0.5(SCN), indicating an oxidation state of +III (BVS value= +2.75) for the Ni atom in the two [Ni(L)(HL)(SCN)] cationic species, to ensure the electroneutrality of the compound. In fact, the presence of the anions, which altogether account for −1.5 charge, excludes the possibility of Ni(II) atoms in the two independent cationic complexes, regardless of the charge (−1 or 0) on the Schiff base ligands. Since the geometrical coordination parameters are very similar and comparable within their esd's (Table S1 and S2), we limit the discussion to complex Ni1 (Fig. 1a). The Ni-O, Ni-N(imino) and Ni-N(amino) bond distances for the tridentate ligand are of 1.900(4), 1.901(5) and 2.036(5) Å, respectively, where a difference of 0.1 Å is detected between the different hybridized nitrogen donors. On the other hand, the Ni-O and Ni-N figures for the chelating ligand are 1.879(4) and 1.944(5) Å. The Ni-NCS bond length falls in the same range, of 1.920(5) Å. These bond distances are quite short, indicating a low spin state of the Ni(III) centers; however, the probable presence of dynamic Jahn-Teller distortion has made all the bond distances comparable in the present case. The N1-Ni1-O3 and O3-Ni1-N5 bond angles, of 83.7(2) and 169.6(2)°, respectively, are those most deviating from the ideal octahedral geometry. It is worth of note the different orientation of the SCN bound to the metal in the two complexes Ni1 and Ni2, being the CN-Ni bond angle of 147.1(5) and 161.1(7)°, respectively. Fig. 2 illustrates a side view of the complexes showing the different orientation of the ethyl(dimethylamino) groups and SCN‒ anions. The [Ni(Cl)(SCN)3][2]‒ anion exhibits two thiocyanate coordinated via S, one via N, and presents a geometry close to tetrahedral. The crystal packing evidences the two different complexes paired through a strong π…π interaction involving the phenol rings O3 and O7 (at 1-x, 1-y, 1-z) with a centroid to centroid distance of 3.573(4) Å, angle between rings of 1.5(3)°. The protonated amino nitrogen atoms are involved in H-bonds, intramolecular or with N and S atoms of the [Ni(Cl)(SCN)3]2− anion (Table S3); however, all these species at half occupancy do not deserve a detailed discussion. As comparison, we report the synthesis and structural characterization of the corresponding Ni(II) complex with the deprotonated Schiff base and SCN‒ ion, [NiII(L)(SCN)3] (2). This was obtained from the synthesis of compound 1 by using bulk KPF6 that removed the [NiII(Cl)(SCN)3]2- component. In the crystal the complex is located on a mirror plane, so that the -CH2CH2N(CH3)2 fragment is disordered over two positions (Ortep view reported in Fig. 3 ). Here the Ni adopts a square planar coordination geometry with Ni-O1 bond distance of 1.842(3) Å, and Ni-N1/2/3 of 1.849(3), 1.959(4) and 1.877(3) Å, respectively, all values are slightly shorter than those measured in mononuclear octahedral complexes of 1, usual for square planar system. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy of compound 1 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was used to investigate the elemental oxidation state of the synthesized compound 1. The overall curve fitting of the XPS analysis is shown in Figure S1. Fig. 4 presents the high-resolution XPS spectra of Ni 2p. The spectrum contains two spin-orbit doublets at binding energy (B.E.) values of 855.58 and 872.67 eV, with a spin energy separation value of 17.09 eV, corresponding to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 components, respectively. The B.E. values at 861.52 and 880.75 eV represent the satellite peaks of Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2. The deconvolution of the Ni 2p3/2 component reveals a pair of peaks with B.E. values of 855.58 and 856.32 eV, assigned to Ni2+ and Ni3+ peaks [50]. The presence of the peak at 873.98 eV also confirms the existence of the Ni3+ ion [51]. The XPS spectra of complex 2 showed two peaks 854.18 and 871.98 eV can be assigned to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of Ni(II), while another two satellite peaks are appeared at 860.02 and 876.98 eV (Figure S2) [53]. UV–Vis data for complex 1 The absorbance spectrum of 1, recorded in acetonitrile at room temperature, exhibits three different bands, an intense peak at 314 nm, a small one at 369 nm and an intense broad at 852 nm (Fig. 5 ). The first two peaks are due to intra-ligand charge transfer transitions (ILCT) and the last one is due to ligand to metal charge transfer transitions (LMCT) involving Ni(III) center and phenoxo group [48,52,54]. The theoretical spectrum, obtained from TD-DFT calculations [54] on the optimized structure of Ni(III) part, exhibits a strong band at around 844 nm due to the electronic transition of S0→S4 (Fig-S3), which well corroborates (Table S5) with the experimental band at 852 nm for Ni(III). Similarly square planar Ni(II) complex (2) exhibits three intense peaks at 398 nm, 495 nm and 682 nm in UV–Vis spectra (Fig-S4) due to intra ligand charge transfer (ILCT), Metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT) and d–d transition respectively. EPR spectroscopy and magnetic studies for compound 1 The Ni(III) and Ni(II) centers of complex 1 are octahedral and square planar respectively. From theory, the octahedral Ni(III) is EPR active and the X-band EPR spectra of powdered complex 1 at room (300 K, Fig. 6 a) and low (77 K, Fig. 6b) temperatures support the presence of a Ni(III) center with a ground state, low-spin, d7 electronic system, t2g 6 eg 1, indicating an octahedral Ni(III) (Fig. 6) [55]. The unpaired electron is on the dx2-y[2] or dz2 orbital depending on geometry. It is quite axial (the first two peaks are almost separated from each other, the second peak is bigger in height) with three principal g values of 2.151, 2.154, and 2.052 for room temperature and 2.063, 2.059, and 2.052 for low temperature data, respectively. In EPR at 77 K, hyperfine coupling to the one axial N donors (I = 1) is observed in the gz direction. However, the given EPR spectrum in Fig. 6 is more axial than rhombic, indicating g(parallel) > g(perpendicular). This suggests that the unpaired electron is located in the dx2-y[2] orbital. In this case, an axial distortion (compression) will place the dx2-y[2] orbital lower in energy, hence, the electron is located in this orbital. The theoretical spin densities based on DFT for 1 evidences the existence of NiIII center assuming low spin state of Ni(III) as doublet spin multiplicity with one unpaired electron, with the unpaired electron prevailing mostly (∼92 %) on the metal center, along with some input (∼7 %) from the two phenoxo O atoms (Fig. 7 ). Moreover, this type of system is always susceptible to being in equilibrium to a certain extent between two tautomeric forms, namely low-spin Ni(III)-phenoxide and Ni(II)-phenoxyl radical forms. Thus, the appearance of a sharp signal at 77 K in the EPR spectrum cannot rule out the possible presence of the Ni(II)-phenoxyl radical tautomeric form to some extent. Temperature-dependent direct current (dc) magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on a polycrystalline sample of complex 1 in the temperature range from 2 to 300 K under an external magnetic field of 1.0 kOe, with the data plotted as χT vs. T, where χ represents molar magnetic susceptibility (Figure S5). At room temperature, the χT value for complex 1 is 0.85 cm3 mol–1 K, which is consistent with two non-interacting low-spin Ni(III) ions (S = ½) per asymmetric unit, with an average g value slightly above 2.0. Isothermal magnetization data at 2 K further support a low-spin doublet ground state (S = ½) for the Ni(III) ions. Upon cooling, the χT values remain almost constant before decreasing at very low temperature, reaching a minimum value of 0.54 cm3 mol–1 K. This plot is typical for a mononuclear complex with a uniform spin state, and the decrease in the χT product is attributed to intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions at low temperatures. The magnetic data were simultaneously fitted using the PHI program, considering only the isotropic Zeeman term (gNi) and the intermolecular interaction parameter zj, which resulted in the best-fit parameters of gNi = 2.08(1) and zj = –0.34(1) cm–1. Interestingly, the extracted gNi parameter agrees well with the average value obtained from the EPR study. Overall, the magnetic study strongly supports the low-spin Ni(III) state in complex 1. However, the possibility of a valence tautomeric equilibrium involving low-spin Ni(III)-phenoxo and high-spin Ni(II)-phenoxyl radical species, as indicated by the EPR study, cannot be ruled out by magnetic measurements, as both systems would ultimately result in an S = ½ ground state. Electrochemistry The electrochemistry of nickel complexes 1 and 2 has been carried out through cyclic voltammetry (CV) in acetonitrile with scan rate of 100 mV/s utilizing Pt-tip as working electrode, platinum rod as counter electrode and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode with TBAP (tetraethylammonium perchlorate) as supporting electrolyte. The ferrocenium/ferrocene couple has been used as an internal standard for all these electrochemical experiments. The CV plot (Fig. 8 ) of complex 1 exhibits two successive reversible peaks at E1/ 21 = 0.545 V and E1/2 2= 0.746 V, with a separation of half wave potential of 0.201 V, whereas that of complex 2 (Figure S6) showed one reversible peak at E1/ 2 = 0.631 V. The controlled coulometric experiments correspond to the ligand based one electron oxidation process due to phenoxyl/phenolate couple [56]. In complex 1, the separation between half wave potentials is relatively large. This feature highlights that the oxidation of one phenolate group in the complex significantly manipulates the second one, consequently the possible structural rearrangement in the coordination sphere during oxidation induces the presence in this complex of a strong electrochemical connection via bonds and space with two chemically identical phenolate moieties [56b]. Catalysis Experimental and theoretical investigations have established that the simultaneous presence of an acidic and basic Lewis site in a complex facilitates the cycloaddition reaction of carbon dioxide and epoxides [57]. The Lewis acidic site (transition metal) activates the epoxides, whereas the Lewis basic site (such as amine or substituted amine) activates the CO2 molecule. In complex 1 the Lewis acidic nickel center and basic sites (i.e. the non co-ordinated -NMe2/-OMe groups) encouraged us to perform the coupling reaction of CO2 and epoxides. After activation of epoxide by the acidic center, ring opening of the epoxide is essential for the further continuation of the reaction. For this purpose, a nucleophile is required to act as co-catalyst for the reaction. Here, in order to optimize the catalytic reaction, we initially used 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane (as a model epoxide) (12 mmol), carbon dioxide (1 bar), complex 1 (as catalyst) (0.005 mmol), and tetrabutyl ammonium bromide (TBAB, 0.05 mmol) as co-catalyst in the reaction. The reaction, performed at 60 °C, yielded 53 % of 4-(chloromethyl)−1,3-dioxolan-2-one after 10 h (Table 1 , entry 1). Without the co-catalyst, the reaction produced only trace amounts of the product (Table 1, entry 2), whereas in the presence of TBAB as the sole catalyst, the reaction produced 18 % of the desired product (Table 1, entry 3). Therefore, the synergistic effect of the catalyst and co-catalyst facilitated the reaction smoothly. Next, different co-catalysts were tested for the reaction (Table 1, entries 4–8), but the results clearly indicated TBAB as the most suitable co-catalyst (entry 1). The Br– anion has greater nucleophilicity than I– and higher leaving capability than Cl–, that is why TBAB, along with complex 1, showed the highest efficiency in this catalytic reaction [58]. Utilizing complex 2 as catalyst in the same reaction with TBAB as co-catalyst resulted in a 46 % yield of the desired product after 10 h (Table 1, entry 9). The slightly lower yield, compared to complex 1 (53 %), is due to the presence of the counter anion [Ni(Cl)(SCN)3]2– in 1. As a result, the increased number of Lewis acidic nickel centers in complex 1 slightly enhances the catalytic activity and, consequently, the product yield. On the other hand, using the ligand (HL) and metal precursor NiCl2·6H2O in place of complex 1, a similar amount of product was obtained as when only the co-catalyst TBAB was used (Table 1, entries 10, 11). The results showed that nickel under the Schiff base ligand (HL) environment, in the presence of TBAB, performed the catalytic reaction most effectively. Hence, the counter anion moiety [Ni(Cl)(SCN)3]2– in 1 has only a minor effect on the catalysis. After selecting the co-catalyst and other parameters such as temperature, catalyst, and co-catalyst loading, the reaction kinetics was optimized in the presence of complexes 1 and 2 (Fig. 9 and Figure S7). A better yield percentage of the desired product was obtained by increasing the reaction temperature. This increases the number of effective collisions between the reactants, and as a result, an optimum yield (i.e., 100 %) was achieved at 90 °C (Fig. 9a). Furthermore, stepwise increasing the dose of co-catalyst from 0.01 to 0.05 mmol in the presence of complex 1 (0.005 mmol) as catalyst at 90 °C, the amount of the corresponding carbonate yield also rises (Fig. 9b) due to enhanced nucleophilic attack towards the activated epoxides with the addition of bromide ions (Br–) from tetra-butylammonium bromide. Thereafter, catalyst loading for the reaction was checked by keeping the co-catalyst loading fixed (0.05 mmol). Fig. 9c shows that 0.005 mmol catalyst is sufficient to maximize the yield percentage of 4-(chloromethyl)−1,3-dioxolan-2-one. Using 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane (12 mmol), catalyst (0.005 mmol), and TBAB (0.05 mmol) under 1 bar CO2 pressure at 90 °C, the kinetics of the catalytic reaction was monitored, and 10 h of reaction were found to produce 100 % conversion of the reactant (Fig. 9d), whereas compound 2 required more time (10.5 h) for the optimum conversion of the reactant (Figure S7d). After reaching the optimal conditions for the catalytic reaction, different epoxides were monitored as substrates using complexes 1 and 2 as catalysts with TBAB as co-catalyst (Table 2 ). Aliphatic epoxides, namely 2-methyloxirane, 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane, 2-((allyloxy)methyl)oxirane, and 2-isobutoxyoxirane, smoothly underwent this reaction with a high yield (83–100 %) of the desired product within 10–14.5 h (Table 2, entries 1–8). Although 2-methyloxirane and 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane gave the maximum conversion (i.e., 100 %) of the desired product (Table 2, entries 1–4), the reaction rate was faster in the case of 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane due to the presence of chlorine, which quickly promotes CO bond cleavage to generate the respective carbonate. On the other hand, increasing the side chain length of epoxides reduces the product yield percentage due to the enhanced steric bulk of the molecule (Table 2, entries 5–8). Aromatic epoxides such as 2-(phenoxymethyl)-oxirane and 2-phenyloxirane produce a relatively lower quantity of carbonate product (60–71 %) after a longer reaction time (16 h) (Table 2, entries 9–12). Cyclohexene epoxide, an endocyclic epoxide, also undergoes this catalytic reaction with a moderate yield (56 %) of cyclohexene carbonate (Table 2, entries 13,14). In each catalytic reaction, high turnover numbers (TON) (1224–2400) and turnover frequencies (TOF) (66–240) were observed. The absence of the nickel counter anion [Ni(Cl)(SCN)3]2− in complex 2 resulted in a slightly lower quantity of the respective cyclic carbonate product after relatively longer reaction times in each case. The catalytic result for the production of 4-methyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one from 2-methyloxirane is compared in Table S6 with those of other previously published Ni(II) complex catalysts. The collection of results clearly show that most nickel(II) catalysts produced the desired product under high carbon dioxide pressure (0.98–3 MPa). Only a couple of publications depicts moderate to high percentages (61–91 %) of 4-methyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one product under 1 bar (0.1 MPa) CO2 pressure in an acetonitrile solvent medium. Thus, our synthesized nickel(III) complex with a Ni(II) counterpart (1) and Ni(II) complex (2) produced a high percentage (96–97 %) of 4-methyl-1,3-dioxolan-2-one through a CO2 (1 atm) fixation reaction under solvent-free, green conditions. DFT calculations to elucidate the catalytic mechanism The X-ray diffraction/XPS studies confirm that the Schiff base complex 1 contains Ni(III) centers, where Ni(III) is theoretically competent to activate 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane through the O-atoms. This is the primary step driving the catalytic process towards the corresponding carbonate synthesis. We employed DFT/Gen for all theoretical calculations of the cyclic carbonate synthesis from chloromethyl oxirane and CO2 catalyzed by complex 1 (computation details reported in the ESI). From experimental evidence and comparisons with previous outcomes [7–8], it is observed that the 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane molecule is activated by the surface of the nickel(III) atom of complex 1 through the oxygen atom of epoxide in 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane (structure-I) to initiate the catalytic reaction. The individual energies for all intermediates and transition states involved in the catalytic reaction of 2-(chloromethyl)oxirane and CO2 are shown in Fig. 10 . Initially, the catalytic site of complex 1 is assumed neutral in calculations. As the catalytic reaction progresses, the chloromethyl oxirane reacts with CO2 in the presence of the catalyst to sequentially form TS-1 (dNi…Ooxirane = 2.11 Å) (11.20 × 10 kcal mol–1), intermediate-I (−15.30 × 10 kcal mol-1), and intermediate-II (−23.64 × 10 kcal mol–1). Hence, TS-2 (−20.32 × 10 kcal mol–1) releases the final product (−23.27 × 10 kcal mol–1), liberating the catalytic Ni(III) center, which re-starts the reaction cycle for complex 1. The possible mechanism for the formation of cyclic carbonate is illustrated in Fig. 11 , based on experimental results and theoretical simulations. Initially, the Lewis acidic nickel center of complex 1 activates the epoxide substrate to produce intermediate-I (Int-1). The nucleophile Br−, generated from TBAB, opens the ring of the activated epoxide of Int-1 to generate the Ni-bonded bromo‑alkoxide (Int-2). Then nucleophilic attack by Int-2 on carbon dioxide produces intermediate-III (Int-3), which subsequently releases the desired carbonate product via an intramolecular ring-closure reaction in the next step, leaving the catalyst free for the next cycle. Conclusion A Ni(III) complex with a Ni(II) counterpart and a Ni(II) complex were synthesized using the Schiff base ligand (E)−4‑bromo-2-(((2-(dimethylamino)ethyl)imino)methyl)−6-methoxyphenol [HL]. X-ray experiments on single crystals elucidated the structure of the synthesized complexes. XPS, EPR, magnetic property studies and electrochemical analyses were performed for complex 1 to confirm the presence of Ni(III). The complexes were used as efficient catalysts in the catalytic process for CO2 fixation to produce cyclic carbonates. This process is favored by the presence of a Lewis acidic center (nickel) as well as Lewis basic -NMe2 and/or -OMe groups in these complexes. The Lewis acidic site (nickel) activates the epoxide molecule, while the basic site activates the carbon dioxide molecule. Aliphatic, aromatic, as well as endocyclic epoxides actively participate in the catalytic CO2 fixation reaction, producing moderate to high yields (51–100 %) of the corresponding cyclic carbonate products at 90 °C, under 1 bar CO2 pressure. The neat conditions make this catalytic method environmentally benign. The catalytic reactions proceed with high ranges of TON (1224–2400) and TOF (66–200 h-1) values. Theoretical investigations were conducted to evaluate the energy of the intermediates, transition states, and products to assess the plausible mechanism of the catalytic reaction. In summary, this study reports the first Ni(III) complex of Schiff base used as an effective catalyst for the synthesis of valuable bio-source cyclic carbonates via CO2 fixation under solvent-free and mild reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: A Ni(III) complex with a Ni(II) counterpart, formulated as 2[Ni(L)(HL)(SCN)].0.5[Ni(Cl)(SCN)3].0.5(SCN) (1), and a Ni(II) complex, [Ni(L)(NCS)] (2), were synthesized using the Schiff base ligand (E)-4‑bromo-2-(((2-(dimethylamino)ethyl)imino)methyl)-6-methoxyphenol [HL]. Both complexes were structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The high oxidation state of the metal in 1 was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), cyclic voltammetry (CV), and EPR analysis study, which, as far as our survey shows, represents the first report of a Ni(III) complex comprising Schiff base ligands with a Ni(II) counterpart. The presence of the Lewis acidic nickel center, as well as the Lewis basic groups (-NMe2 or -OMe) in both complexes, makes them suitable as catalysts for carbon dioxide fixation into epoxides for the production of organic cyclic carbonates. The use of greenhouse gas CO2 (at 1 bar) and solvent-free conditions marks the catalytic protocol as environment friendly. Various aliphatic, aromatic, and endocyclic epoxides smoothly undergo the fixation reaction through this catalytic process, producing the respective carbonate products in moderate to high yields (51–100 %) at 90 °C. The conditions of these catalytic reactions were optimized, and high turnover numbers (TON) of 1224–2400, along with turnover frequencies of 66–200 h–1, were achieved. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used to determine the relative energy of transition states, intermediates, and products involved in the catalytic cycles and to describe the mechanistic pathway in detail.
